awd_titl_txt: Five Languages of Eurasia: Field Work, Analysis and Digital Archiving

por.por_cntn:
NSF grant 0553546, Five Languages of Eurasia, resulted, first of all, in sixteen expeditions to remote and dangerous parts of the continent: far North (the Taimyr peninsula), far East (Kamchatka and Sakhalin), and the Caucasus (Azerbaijan and the autonomous republic of Dagestan within the Russian Federation). Travels to Taimyr and Kamchatka were particularly arduous. Dagestan has been steadily descending into violence and most of it is now practically off-limits for field linguists.

The project's expeditions brought back many hours of high-quality recordings, made with the state-of-the-art equipment provided by the grant. Many of those recordings have been transcribed, linguistically analyzed, and annotated, in accordance with the best practices of language documentation. The languages so documented are: Archi (Dagestan), Khinalug (Azerbaijan), Alutor (Kamchatka), Nganasan (Taimyr), and Ulita (Sakhalin). For three of these languages, Alutor, Archi, and Khinalug, writing systems have been developed. The original five languages of the project did not include Ulita, but did include Enets, another language of Taimyr. However, the language is practically extinct, and it proved impossible to find native speakers who would be competent enough to make new recordings. The archive created by the project does include older Enets recordings (the Forest dialect) that were upgraded and re-annotated.

The greatest technological achievement of the project, not foreseen in the initial grant proposal, was the creation of the Moscow digital language archive center "LangueDOC," housed at the Department of Theoretical and Applied Linguistics of Moscow State University. The archive is a node in a global network of language archives centered at the Max-Planck Institute for Psycholinguistics (MPI-Nijmegen). All the nodes in the network use the software platform for archiving and online access to multimedia language data that has been developed at MPI. Apart from the data from Five Languages of Eurasia, the LangueDOC archive hosts contributions from several language documentation projects including Eastern Khanty (Uralic), Evenki (Tungusic), Ket (Yenissean) and Selkup (Samoyedic), as well as corpora of Russian intonation, Russian sign language and Russian gesticulation. A participant of the project, Dr. Alexandre Arkhipov, serves as the Director of the archive and has conducted several workshops for Russian linguists on how to create field materials and prepare them for archiving. Materials on language documentation have also been included in courses taught at the Department of Theoretical and Applied Linguistics, and there are plans to publish a textbook based on those course materials.

In addition to language archives, the NSF project has supported the creation of grammatical materials on the languages of the project: dictionaries; selected inflectional paradigms; and phonetic databases, each containing about 300–400 wordforms per language that together represent every phoneme in most relevant phonological contexts, recorded with several speakers. Together with archival holdings, these primary data form a solid basis for further studies in grammar and phonology of the languages of the project, and in fact have already served for a great number of scholarly articles and conference presentations created with the support of the project.

The archive can be found at http://languedoc.philol.msu.ru/ds/imdi_browser/; additional materials are at the website for the project, http://www.philol.msu.ru/~languedoc/.
